page_analysis.text_content:
Projections
Architectural relief
features such as bay
windows are pleasant
additions to a house
design and are
encouraged. If they
meet certain design
criteria they do not
count toward gross
floor area.
Bay windows
Bay windows that meet the design criteria below are considered to be decorative
architectural features and do NOT count toward gross floor area.
Design criteria for bay windows that do not count:
• Bottom of feature must be at least 18" above the floor joists
• Exterior supports must be features like corbels and/or brackets
rather than solid walls
• At least 50% of the surface is glass
Fig 13 Bay windows
2' max. from bay window
surface to facade surface
(Typical all)
Note: Bay windows that ex-
tend higher than the struc-
ture's roof are considered
to be dormers and count to-
ward gross floor area.
Code sections
18.04.030(a)(65)
18.12.040(b)Table 3
A
Does NOT count
B
Counts because floor
joists continue into the
bay window
C & D
Count because of exterior skirt wall
(angled or straight)
E
Counts because the
surface is not at least
50% glass
18

visual_elements.description: A series of five cross-sectional diagrams (labeled A, B, C, D, E) illustrating different types of bay window constructions and whether they count towards gross floor area. Each diagram shows a portion of a building wall with a bay window extending outwards. Diagram A shows a bay window that does not count, with a clear 18" minimum clearance from the floor joists. Diagram B shows a bay window where floor joists continue into the bay window, indicating it counts. Diagrams C & D show bay windows with an exterior skirt wall (angled or straight), indicating they count. Diagram E shows a bay window with less than 50% glass surface, indicating it counts. There is also a dimension line indicating '2' max. from bay window surface to facade surface (Typical all)' and '18" min. from top of floor to bottom of baywindow structure'.

technical_specifications.parameter: Minimum height of bay window bottom above floor joists
Minimum glass surface percentage for bay window not to count
Maximum projection from bay window surface to facade surface

subheadings: Design criteria for bay windows that do not count:
sections: Architectural relief features such as bay windows are pleasant additions to a house design and are encouraged. If they meet certain design criteria they do not count toward gross floor area.
Bay windows that meet the design criteria below are considered to be decorative architectural features and do NOT count toward gross floor area.
B Counts because floor joists continue into the bay window
C & D Count because of exterior skirt wall (angled or straight)
E Counts because the surface is not at least 50% glass

additional_notes: The page number '18' is located at the bottom left corner.
The text 'Bottom of teature' appears to be a typo and should likely be 'Bottom of feature'.
